item.title: AI Startup Cohere Has Doubled Sales So Far This Year, CEO Says
item.description: Cohere Inc. Chief Executive Officer Aidan Gomez said the artificial intelligence startup has “more than doubled” its revenue since the start of this year and is approaching profitability, even as it faces heightened competition for business customers from OpenAI and Anthropic.
item.dc:creator: Seth Fiegerman, Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: Aidan Gomez, chief executive officer of Cohere Inc., following a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023. UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak was hoping his AI summit would bring heads of the most powerful nations face-to-face with executives to guard against the technology's “catastrophic” potential.

item.title: Apple to Open AI Models to Developers, Betting That It Will Spur New Apps
item.description: Apple Inc. is preparing to allow third-party developers to write software using its artificial intelligence models, aiming to spur the creation of new applications and make its devices more enticing.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Apple Intelligence signage outside the company's Fifth Avenue store in New York, US, on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025. Apple Inc., as it seeks relief from US President Donald Trump's tariffs on goods imported from China, said that it will hire 20,000 new workers and produce AI servers in the US.

item.title: Microsoft-Backed Startup Builder.ai to File for Insolvency
item.description: Builder.ai, the British artificial intelligence startup backed by Microsoft Corp. and the Qatar Investment Authority, will file an insolvency case after overstating sales figures it provided investors.
item.dc:creator: Yazhou Sun

media:content.media:description: The Builder.ai logo.

item.title: Musk Commits to Tesla CEO Role and Plans Political Pullback
item.description: Elon Musk said he’s committed to still leading Tesla Inc. in five years and expects to pare back his political spending, assuaging some investors’ concerns about the future of his most valuable company.
item.dc:creator: Dana Hull, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk speaks via video link at the Qatar Economic Forum on May 20. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Are Deepfakes Everywhere? Can They Be Stopped?
item.description: The internet is awash in deepfakes — audio, pictures or video made using artificial intelligence tools in which people appear to do or say things they didn’t, be somewhere they weren’t, or that change their appearance. Some involve nudification, where photos are altered to depict someone unclothed. Other deepfakes are deployed to scam consumers, or to damage the reputations of politicians and other people in the public eye.
item.dc:creator: Nate Lanxon, Omar El Chmouri

media:content.media:description: The news conference to unveil the Take It Down Act, in Washington, DC, in June 2024. Photographer: Andrew Harnik/Getty Images

item.title: Amazon’s Zoox Expands Robotaxi Trials to Rival Turf in Atlanta
item.description: Amazon.com Inc.’s Zoox is expanding testing of its autonomous driving technology to Atlanta, moving in on a market where Alphabet Inc.’s Waymo is expanding with Uber Technologies Inc.
item.dc:creator: Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: A Zoox autonomous robotaxi in San Francisco, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Pony AI Robotaxi Revenue Triples Ahead of Commercialization
item.description: Pony AI Inc.’s first-quarter robotaxi revenue tripled with the Chinese autonomous vehicle firm setting its sights on large-scale commercialization of services later this year.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Pony AI Robotaxis.

item.title: Alphabet Traders Look to Developer Event to Shift AI Narrative
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s investors are looking to this week’s developer conference to see if the company can reset the narrative amid fears that its long-standing market dominance is on shaky ground.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

media:content.media:description: The Google Cloud Next "25: AI Exclusive at the Sphere" event in April.

item.title: Telefonica Said to Study Raising Stake in Brazil Fiber Unit
item.description: Telefonica SA is weighing increasing its stake in a fiber-optic broadband venture it owns in Brazil, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga, Paula Sambo

item.title: Malaysia Downplays Huawei Deal as US Checks China’s AI Reach
item.description: Malaysia declared it’ll build a first-of-its-kind AI system powered by Huawei Technologies Co. chips, only to distance itself from that statement a day later, underscoring the Asian nation’s delicate position in the US-Chinese AI race.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. chip.

item.title: AI Advances Are Accelerating, and We’re Not Ready
item.description: The economic and societal impact could be massive.
item.dc:creator: Brad Stone

item.title: Thoma Bravo Nears Deal for Insurance Tech Firm Itel
item.description: Thoma Bravo has agreed to acquire GTCR-backed Itel, an insurance technology firm focused on property and casualty claims services.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Thoma Bravo private equity firm in the Brickell neighborhood of Miami, Florida, US, on Wednesday, March 5, 2025. Since the current iteration of Thoma Bravo was founded in 2008, it's been involved in roughly a fifth of all private equity buyouts in the sector as measured by value, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Photographer: Scott McIntyre/Bloomberg

item.title: Ex-NBC Host Chuck Todd Plans Online Show With Startup Noosphere
item.description: Chuck Todd, the former moderator of NBC’s weekly news program Meet the Press, is launching a new app-based show with media startup Noosphere.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miller

media:content.media:description: Chuck Todd Source: Noosphere

item.title: Inside the First Stargate AI Data Center
item.description: OpenAI, Oracle and SoftBank hope that the site in Texas is the first of many across the US.
item.dc:creator: Shirin Ghaffary, Brody Ford, Emily Chang

media:content.media:description: The future home of the first Stargate site in Abilene, Texas.

item.title: Nik Storonsky’s AI Venture Firm Raises $250 Million for Startups
item.description: Billionaire Nik Storonsky’s artificial intelligence-focused venture capital firm has completed a funding round of $250 million as it steps up its hunt for fresh startups for investment.
item.dc:creator: Aisha S Gani

media:content.media:description: Nikolay Storonsky Photographer: Benjamin Cremel/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Why Is Nvidia the King of AI Chips, and Can It Last?
item.description: After a blistering share rally that for a time made Nvidia Corp. the world’s most valuable company, investors have become more wary of pouring more money into the chipmaker, aware that the adoption of artificial intelligence computing won’t be a straight path, and won’t rely solely on Nvidia technology.
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: Nvidia H100

item.title: Nvidia CEO’s Growing Presence Transcends Technology
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter with reporting and analysis about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Vlad Savov looks at the diplomatic errands that accompany the job of being a modern tech CEO.
item.dc:creator: Vlad Savov

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, co-founder and CEO of Nvidia Corp., speaks during the Hill & Valley forum at the US Capitol on April 30. The forum is a gathering of lawmakers and venture capitalists focused on the US tech industry.

item.title: Vodafone’s CEO Says End Is in Sight for German Sales Declines
item.description: Vodafone Group Plc Chief Executive Officer Margherita Della Valle said the company’s biggest market, Germany, may return to revenue growth in the current fiscal year after heavy competition and a regulatory change cost it millions of customers and pushed down sales.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Deutsch

media:content.media:description: A Vodafone GmbH advertisement. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Tesla Supplier CATL Soars in HK Debut After World’s Top Listing This Year
item.description: Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd. jumped in its Hong Kong trading debut after the Chinese battery giant wrapped up the world’s biggest listing this year by raising HK$35.7 billion ($4.6 billion) despite being blacklisted by the Pentagon and grinding through geopolitical storms.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: CATL Chairman Robin Zeng strikes a gong at the listing ceremony in Hong Kong. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Grab, GoTo Targeted by Indonesia Drivers’ Protest Over Pay
item.description: Grab Holdings Ltd. and GoTo Group were among ride-hailing and delivery services targeted by driver protests on Tuesday in Indonesia, with thousands gathering to demand better compensation and other terms.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara, Olivia Poh

media:content.media:description: Drivers in the ride-hailing and delivery services industry protest in Jakarta on May 20.

item.title: Anglo-African Fund Plans $1 Billion Infrastructure Investment
item.description: South African asset manager Ninety One Ltd. plans to deploy more than $1 billion in critical infrastructure projects in Africa and Asia by 2028, after raising debt from global financial institutions.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: Highway construction in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Photographer: Leon Sadiki/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Smartphone Exports to US Plunge to Lowest Since 2011
item.description: Chinese shipments of Apple Inc.’s iPhone and other mobile devices to the US dived to their lowest levels since 2011 in April, underscoring how the threat of US tariffs choked off the flow of big-ticket goods between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Andy Lin (News), Vlad Savov

media:content.media:description: Apple iPhone 16 smartphones.

item.title: Trump’s Mideast Chips Deals Imperil US National Security, Democrats Warn
item.description: Key Senate Democrats urged the Trump administration to revisit new artificial intelligence deals with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, saying that expanded sales of AI chips to the Middle Eastern countries risk exposing advanced technology to China and Russia, while potentially limiting supplies available for American companies.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Michael Shepard

media:content.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat from Massachusetts and ranking member of Senate Banking committee, co-signed a letter to top Trump administration officials expressing concern that recent AI deals in the Mideast would jeopardize US national security and economic competitiveness.

item.title: China Accuses US of Undermining Trade Talks With Warnings Against Huawei Chips
item.description: The Chinese government accused the Trump administration of undermining recent trade talks in Geneva after it warned that using Huawei Technologies Co.’s artificial-intelligence chips “anywhere in the world” would violate US export controls.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Tam, Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: A corporate logo sits on a Huawei Technologies Co. NetEngine 8000 intelligent metro router on display during a 5G event in London, U.K., on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020. Huawei said at the event it currently has 91 contracts for 5G, with 47 of those in Europe.

item.title: Nintendo Turns to Samsung to Make Chips, Ramp Up Switch 2 Output
item.description: Nintendo Co. has turned to Samsung Electronics Co. to help make the main chips for the Switch 2, a move that may help the Japanese company ramp up production of the gaming console enough to sell a higher-than-projected 20 million units by March 2026.
item.dc:creator: Yoolim Lee, Takashi Mochizuki

media:content.media:description: The Switch 2 at a launch event in Paris on April 2. Photographer: Dimitar Dilkoff/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Bithumb Claims Larger Slice of Korea’s Crypto Space Ahead of IPO
item.description: After years spent in the shadow of larger rival Upbit, crypto exchange Bithumb is clawing back a more meaningful share of South Korea’s tightly held digital-assets market.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

item.title: Nvidia Opens AI Ecosystem to Rivals, Apple AI Struggles | Bloomberg Technology
item.description: Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow breaks down why the Magnificent Seven are lower on Monday as investor sentiment sours more broadly following Moody’s US credit downgrade. Plus, Nvidia says it will allow customers to use rival chipmakers in an effort to expand its AI ecosystem, and Apple has been spending billions of dollars on AI but insiders say it still can't get it right. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Pony AI Earnings Put Investors on Alert for Robotaxi Expansion
item.description: Pony AI Inc.’s report on its first full quarter as a publicly traded company will have investors and analysts homing in on how a new generation of robotaxis could put the firm on a path to profitability.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Kniazhevich

media:content.media:description: A Pony.ai Inc. autonomous vehicle with the branding of the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) travels along a road in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, July 8, 2021. The conference runs through to July 10.

item.title: Google Decided Against Offering Publishers Options in AI Search
item.description: Company drew “hard red line” around requiring web publishers to participate in AI search, document says
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba, Julia Love

media:content.media:description: Signage at the the Google headquarters in Mountain View, California, US, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Alphabet Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on October 24. Photographer David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: US Battery Startup ONE Inks Production Deal With Turkey’s Pomega
item.description: US battery startup Our Next Energy Inc. will outsource some production of its battery cells to Turkey’s Pomega Enerji Depolama Teknolojileri AS.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: UKRAINE - 2022/01/06: In this photo illustration, Our Next Energy Inc. (ONE) logo seen displayed on a smartphone screen. (Photo Illustration by Pavlo Gonchar/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)
